Addresses by Bernard M. Baruch,
internationally noted banker and
financier, and Dr. Joseph S. Ames,
president of the Johns Hopkins University, and the presentation to the
University of a portrait of the late
Dr. John Whitridge Williams will
mark the exercises to be held at 11
a. m., February 22, in the Peabody
Conservatory Auditorium in commemoration of the fifty-seventh anniversary of the inauguration of
Daniel Coit Gilman, first president
of the J. H. U. The topics of the
talks were unknown yesterday.
The portrait of Dr. Williams,
done by the well-known Baltimore
artist, Thomas Corner, who has executed paintings of many members
of the faculty, will be presented to
the Hopkins by Dr. J. H. Stander,
formerly of the J. H. U. and now
professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Cornell Medical College.

"Some New Developments in the
Field of Pyrimidine Chemistry" is
the subject of the A. R. L. Dohme
lecture to be delivered today at 4
—Courtesy The Post
p. m. by Dr. Treat B. Johnson, proBERNARD M. BARUCH
fessor of organic chemistry at Yale
University.
In his lecture, Dr. Johnson will
discuss: (1) description of a new
method of synthesizing "prymine",
(2) general improvements in the
methods of pyrimidine synthesis,
(3) synthesis of pyrimidine-nudeasides, and (4) hunting for the antiSocial Problems Club Meets neuritic vitamin among pyrimidine

Following a short respite as a
result of the mid-term examinations, the undefeated Jay swimming

of the season tomorrow night
against William and Mary College
at K. of C. pool.
Thus far the Hopkins tankmen
have conquered George Washington, Franklin and Marshall, and
Delaware. The most thrilling meet
of the three took place against
Franklin and Marshall, the Jays
earning a 30-29 victory.
Records Shattered

This conquest bore a double significance. In he first place, this was
Hopkins's first swimming victory
over F. and M. in six years. Secondly, the loss was handed to last
season's Eastern Collegiate cham-

Right before your very eyes the man of magic draws
rabbits, vegetables, flowers, fruits—even babies—all
from an empty tub! What an astonishing fellow he is!
EXPLANATION:

The assorted rabbits, babies, carrots, cabbages, ribbons and other magical "props" are not created by
magic. The tub has a false bottom that is conveniently
displaced, and numberless wonderful things spring to
life in the magician's nimble fingers. They do literally "spring" because they are made to compress into
the bottom of the tub, taking their natural shape as
the magician lifts them out.
SOURCE: "Tricks and Illusions" by Will Goldston,
E. P. Dutton er Co.

Addresses by Bernard M. Baruch,
internationally noted banker and
financier, and Dr. Joseph S. Ames,
president of the Johns Hopkins University, and the presentation to the
University of a portrait of the late
Dr. John Whitridge Williams will
mark the exercises to be held at 11
a. m., February 22, in the Peabody
Conservatory Auditorium in commemoration of the fifty-seventh anniversary of the inauguration of
Daniel Coit Gilman, first president
of the J. H. U. The topics of the
talks were unknown yesterday.
The portrait of Dr. Williams,
done by the well-known Baltimore
artist, Thomas Corner, who has executed paintings of many members
of the faculty, will be presented to
the Hopkins by Dr. J. H. Stander,
formerly of the J. H. U. and now
professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Cornell Medical College.

"Some New Developments in the
Field of Pyrimidine Chemistry" is
the subject of the A. R. L. Dohme
lecture to be delivered today at 4
—Courtesy The Post
p. m. by Dr. Treat B. Johnson, proBERNARD M. BARUCH
fessor of organic chemistry at Yale
University.
In his lecture, Dr. Johnson will
discuss: (1) description of a new
method of synthesizing "prymine",
(2) general improvements in the
methods of pyrimidine synthesis,

Following a short respite as a
result of the mid-term examinations, the undefeated Jay swimming
team will stage its first home duel
of the season tomorrow night
against William and Mary College
at K. of C. pool.
Thus far the Hopkins tankmen
have conquered George Washington, Franklin and Marshall, and
Delaware. The most thrilling meet
of the three took place against
Franklin and Marshall, the Jays
earning a 30-29 victory.
Records Shattered

This conquest bore a double significance. In he first place, this was
Hopkins's first swimming victory
over F. and M. in six years. Secondly, the loss was handed to last
season's Eastern Collegiate cham-

Right before your very eyes the man of magic draws
rabbits, vegetables, flowers, fruits—even babies—all
from an empty tub! What an astonishing fellow he is!
EXPLANATION:

The assorted rabbits, babies, carrots, cabbages, ribbons and other magical "props" are not created by
magic. The tub has a false bottom that is conveniently
displaced, and numberless wonderful things spring to
life in the magician's nimble fingers. They do literally "spring" because they are made to compress into
the bottom of the tub, taking their natural shape as
the magician lifts them out.
SOURCE: "Tricks and Illusions" by Will Goldston,
E. P. Dutton er Co.
